did.unittitle: University of Virginia School of Medicine Student Notebook Collection

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: University of Virginia School of Medicine Student Notebook Collection, Accession #MS-37, Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The notebooks were donated by various people including Dr. Malcolm Foote Sher, Dr. Porter B. Echols, Jr., the Dr. Armistead P. Booker family, Dr. Weaver, Ms. Roberta Senechal, Jethro Meriwether Hurt, III, Mr. James Skalnik, and James D. Webb. Several notebooks were purchased.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: The student notebooks contain the notes that medical students took in their classes or laboratories at the University of Virginia. Some of the notebooks belonged to men who would become faculty members at UVa. Those include Armistead Page Booker who was Clinical Instructor in Pediatrics in 1947 and retired from his position of Associate Professor in 1985; William Beverly Towles who became an instructor in anatomy in the 1872-73 session and became Professor of Anatomy and Materia Medica, serving in that position until his death in 1893; Charles Bruce Morton who is listed as the Professor of Clinical Surgery and Gynecology in the "University of Virginia Record" for 1944-45 and was last listed in the "University of Virginia School of Medicine Record" for 1969-70; and Oscar Swineford was listed as an instructor in Medicine in the "University of Virginia Record" of March 15, 1928 and was last listed as a Professor of Internal Medicine in the 1966-67 "University of Virginia Record."

Many of the students included the names of their professors and instructors and those include John Staige Davis, James L. Cabell, John P. Emmet, Henry Howard, Socrates Maupin, Albert H. Tuttle, Stephen Hurt Watts, John Henry Neff, William Hall Goodwin, Lawrence T. Royster, Allen F. Voshell, E. Wood, John Campbell Hortenstine, Henry Bearden Mulholland, Edwin Partridge Lehman, William Henry Parker, William Roland Hill, Charles Bruce Morton, William Edward Bray, Kenneth Boyd Grim, Samuel Alexander Vest, Edgar Wilson Kirby, Bruno Barelare, Tiffany Johns Williams, John McIntire Nokes, William Wirt Waddell, McLemore Birdsong, William Gayle Crutchfield, Everett Cato Drash, Edwin Webster Shearburn, Byrd Stuart Leavell, William Maryon Moir, David Cole Wilson, Thomas Shepherd Englar, Byrd Stuart Leavell, Oscar Swineford, Staige Davis Blackford, John Osborne McNeel, James Alexander Waddell, Dudley Crofford Smith, Fletcher Drummond Woodward, Vincent William Archer, George Cooper, Eugene Markley Landis, George McLean Lawson, Claude C. Coleman, Theodore Hough, William Douglas Macon, William Edward Brown, and Leroy Adelbert Calkins.

In our rare book collection there are other items of interest related to the student notebooks. These include the Syllabus of the Lectures on Medical Jurisprudence and on the Treatment of Poisoning and Suspended Animation, Delivered in the University of Virginia, by Robley Dunglison and printed in 1827 as well as volumes related to anatomy by William Beverley Towles. Towles' works are Notes on Anatomy printed in 1886, Anatomy Notes published in 1890, Notes on Anatomy published in 1893, and Descriptive Anatomy published in 1898 and 1904.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The notebooks range from 1836-1943 and include notes taken in classes for anatomy, surgery, physiology, gynecology, midwifery, chemistry, materia medica, preventive medicine, practice of medicine, ENT, bacteriology, jurisprudence, pharmacy, organic chemistry, pathology, psychobiology, internal medicine, toxicology, clinical diagnosis, histology, biology, syphilology, embryology, heart disease, urology, physical diagnosis, dermatology, pediatrics, orthopedics, Roentgenology, edpidemiology, nervous system, case teaching, and insanity.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The first 13 boxes and Box 14 through folder 5 are arranged chronologically. From Box 14, folder 6 the arrangement is in the order received.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Notes on Midwifery 1840-1841

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken at the University of Virginia by Alexander M. Campbell from Dr. Howards' lectures, Session of 1840 and 41. Included are directions for purifying gold, silver solder, gold solder, stannate, flux, and enamels. According to the "Catalogue of the Officers and Students of the University of Virginia," A. M. Campbell, from Amherst, Va., attended UVA in 1840-41 in the schools of Anatomy and Surgery.
Professor: Henry Howard (Professor of Physiology, Medicine, Obstetrics, and Medical Jurisprudence).

Textbook: Alfred Velpeau, Translated from the French with notes by Charles D. Meigs. An Elementary Treatise on Midwifery, or, Principles of Tokology and Embryology (Philadelphia: Grigg & Elliot, 1838).

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Physiology lectures by Dr. J[ames] L. Cabbell [Cabell] 1867 November 14 - 1868 April 16

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by William B. Towles from Cumberland, Virginia. According to the "Catalogue of the University of Virginia, 1868-69," William Beverly Towles received his MD degree in 1869. Dr. Towles, was a distinguished anatomist. He entered the University of Virginia as a student of medicine in 1867. In 1872 he was elected Demonstrator of Anatomy, and, upon the death of Dr. John Staige Davis in 1885, succeeded him as Professor of Anatomy. He worked for the University of Virginia until he died on September 15, 1893.
Schools Attended: Chemistry and Pharmacy, Medicine, Physiology and Surgery, and Anatomy and Materia Medica.
Professor: James L. Cabell (Professor of Physiology and Surgery).

According to the "Catalogue of the University of Virginia, 1968-69," Augustus Middleton Hill was a student during the 1968-69 session.

Textbook: George B. Wood, A Treatise on Therapeutics, and Pharmacology, or Materia Medica (Philadelphia, J.B. Lippincott & Co., 1868).

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by W. Levi Old from Bennett's Creek, Virginia. He had a B.A. from Randolph-Macon College, Virginia. He was a physician and surgeon in London Bridge, Virginia. He served in the Spanish-American War as a major in the Virginia Volunteer Unit Medical Corps. He was a charter member of the American College of Surgeons, and he worked for many years at St. Vincent's Hospital in Norfolk.
Schools Attended: Physiology and Surgery, Anatomy and Materia Medica, Practice of Medicine, Chemistry, and Biology and Agriculture
Professor: Albert H. Tuttle (Professor of Biology)
Textbook: Edward E. Klein, Elements of Histology (Philadelphia: Lea Brothers, 1898).

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Biology B, Botany, Volume I 1916 September 25-1917 May 16
did.physdesc: ADS notebook with drawings, some in color, also bound with copied lecture notes.

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by Charles Bruce Morton. According to the "University of Virginia Record Catalogue," Charles Bruce Morton received his MD degree on June 13, 1922. He also received the B.S. degree from the University of Virginia in 1920. In 1927 Dr. Morton was appointed Assistant Professor of Surgery and Gynecology at the University of Virginia School of Medicine and promoted to full professorship in 1936. During the academic year 1953-54, he served as Acting Chairman of the Department of Surgery. He received the University of Virginia's first award of the John Horsley Memorial Prize for Research in Surgery in 1927 and the President and Board of Visitors Sigma Xi Research Prize in 1928. Dr. Morton was a member of the Executive Committee of the University of Virginia Hospital from 1935 to 1954. He has been an Attending Surgeon and Gynecologist at the University of Virginia Hospital, and an Attending Surgeon on the courtesy staff of Martha Jefferson Hospital, 1927.

In addition to his teaching and surgical practice, Dr. Morton has been active in a number of professional organizations, in which he has held important posts, and he has contributed over seventy articles to medical and surgical publications. His society membership include: International Society of Surgery, American Surgical Association, American College of Surgeons, American Medical Association, Southern Surgical Association (Vice President, 1946), Southeastern Surgical Congress, Eastern Surgical Society (President, 1957), Southern Society of Clinical Surgeons (President, 1946), Virginia Surgical Society (President, 1955), and Medical Society of Virginia.
Professors: Ivey Forman Lewis (Miller Professor of Biology and Agriculture) William Allison Kepner (Associate Professor of Biology)
Class: C. B. Morton took this class when he was an undergraduate student.

After graduating from medical school, Dr. Daniel Oscar Nichols interned at Blue Ridge Sanatorium and the University of Virginia Hospital while also maintaining his practice in Charlottesville. He became a member of the Virginia Academy of General Practice in 1953.

did.unittitle: Notebook: Pathology notes 1930 June 24-August 7

scopecontent.p: The notebook were taken by Oscar Swineford. This is not be a "student" notebook as Swineford graduated from UVa SOM in 1926. The notebook was written when he was teaching as Instructor in Clinical Pathology, 1928-1930. After receiving the B.S. degree in 1923 and the M.D. degree in 1926 at the University of Virginia, Dr. Swineford joined the faculty of the University of Virginia School of Medicine. He became Professor of Internal Medicine and Head of the Allergy Division at the University of Virginia School of Medicine. Hi was important in encouraging medical schools all over the United States to develop the teaching of allergy. He was President of the American Academy of Allergy and the Southeastern Allergy Association. He was Chairman of the Allergy Section of the Southern Medical Association. He was a member of the Scientific and Educational Council of the Allergy Foundation of America, of the American Rheumatism Association, the Medical Society of Virginia, the American Medical Association, and a fellow of the American College of Physicians. Chiarri is written on the front of the notebook and on pages inside but it is not clear if this is a student or instructor name.
Donor: Mrs. Blair, daughter of Dr. Swineford, Jr.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Materia Medica notes 1929-30

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by D. F. Weaver. According to the the "University of Virginia Record," Delmar Franklin Weaver from Orange, Virginia, graduated with an MD degree on June, 14, 1932. After serving as Instructor of Surgery at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, Weaver did a Fellowship at the Rochester, Minnesota, Mayo Clinic in otolaryngology, bronschoscopy and plastic surgery from 1936 to 1939. Later he was associate surgeon in Otolaryngology at Henry Ford Hospital, Detroit. From 1950 to 1970, Weaver was in private practice in Detroit. He was appointed Clinical Professor of Otolaryngology, College of Medicine, Wayne State University in 1963. From 1970 until he retired Weaver was on the staff at Culpeper Memorial Hospital and was a visiting staff member at the UVa Medical Center.
Professor: James Alexander Waddell (Professor of Pharmacology, Materia Medica and Toxicology).

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Calibration of Volumetric Apparatus 1937 August 3-September 28

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by Armistead P. Booker when he was an undergraduate student. According to the "University of Virginia Record," Armistead Page Booker from New Castle, Delaware, graduated with an MD degree on June, 15, 1943. He earned a B.S. from Virginia Military Institute. He was Charlottesville's first full-time pediatrician, and cared for four generations of children. He was a founder of Pediatrics Associates and worked as an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at the University of Virginia where he became Chief of the Pediatric Clinic and Director of the blood bank. He also served as a physician at the Blue Ridge School in Dyke and at Woodrow Wilson Rehabilitation Center in Fisherville. He was Chief of Pediatrics at the Martha Jefferson Hospital. He served in the military for 38 years, including active duty in the Army and Air Force. He was awarded the meritorious service medal and the Army commendation medal. He served in many community and professional posts, and was author of numerous publications.
The inscription on the front cover of the notebook includes "Eastern Laboratory, Gibbstown, N.J." Eastern Laboratory was a research facility developed by DuPont.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Laboratory Notebook in Physiology 1935 November 6
did.physdesc: TDS notebook with A notes, 1 TLS copy

scopecontent.p: The notebook was done by Malcolm Foote Sher and Charlotte Swaney. Sher donated it in 1992. According to the "University of Virginia Record," Malcolm Foote Sher and Charlotte Ellen Swaney both received their MD degrees on June 13, 1938.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Surgery 1936 January - 1937 June

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by Malcolm Foote Sher. According to the "University of Virginia Record," Malcolm Foote Sher received his MD degrees on June 13, 1938. The notebook is divided into sections: General Principles by Dr. [Edwin Partridge] Lehman, Abdominal Surgery by Dr. [Edwin Partridge] Lehman, General Surgery by Dr. [Charles Bruce] Morton, Thoracic Surgery by Dr. [Everett Cato] Drash, Sympath. Surgery by Dr. [Edwin Partridge] Lehman, Neuro Surgery by Dr. [Claude C.] Coleman, Urology by Dr. [John Henry] Neff and Gynecology by Dr. [Charles Bruce] Morton.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Medicine, Materia Medica and Chemistry [1836]

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken William H. Harding. According to the "Catalogue of the Officers and Students of the University of Virginia," Harding attended sessions in 1835-36 and 1836-37. According to the accompanying letter from Palinurus Antiquarian Books, the lectures were given by John Patten Emmet. The letter also indicates that Harding was from a Virginia family in Northumberland County whose estate and plantation still stand, that he practiced medicine and served in the Virginia General Assembly before an untimely death. In the back of the notebook are fragments of letters to people including Ann H. George and his uncle.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Anatomy 1873 October 4 - 1874 June 22

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by Charles Shepherd Webb. According to his brief autobiography, when he attended the University of Virginia, he took a "thorough course in the theoretical branches and then went to the University of New York to get the benefit of the hospitals." He graduated with the degree of M.D. from the University of New York.
The UVa lecturer was John Staige Davis in anatomy. The notebook also contains notes that were given by Professor Darling at the University of New York and another section on materia medica.
The notebook was donated by Ann W. McDowell, Webb's granddaughter, in March 2010.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Notes on Chemistry and Medicine, 1839 September 16 - 1840 March 30

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by Jethro Meriwether Hurt. Hurt attended the University of Virginia for the 1839-40 session and studied Chemistry, Medicine, and Anatomy and Surgery. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Medical School in 1841.

(September 1839-1840 at the University of Virginia): Notes on chemistry (Dr. [John P.] Emmet) -- Chlorosis, page 23, (Dr. [Henry] Howard, March 1840) -- Muscles -- On the treatment of cholera (Dr. Howard) -- Series on the brain and spinal marrow -- Anatomy -- Cholera asphyscia -- Medicine (Dr. Griffith) -- Of yellow fever -- Congestive fever (December 5, 1839) -- Treatment of gastritis -- Symptoms of chronic enteritis -- Diarrhoea acute and chronic -- Causes of hepatitis -- Symptoms of meningitis -- General cerebritis -- Dr. [James L.] Cabell notes (1839) -- Dr. Howard notes.
Gift of Jethro Meriwether Hurt, III. Fragile with brittle pages.

did.unittitle: Student notebook 1840

scopecontent.p: Volume 2 (1840 continued ) -- Howard's lecture on midwifery -- Haemorrage -- Metritis on puerpera fever -- Signs of delivery -- Rape -- Latent diseases -- Survivorship -- Wounds --- Persons found dead -- Adipocere -- Poisons -- Cough mixture [and other remedies and ointments].
Gift of Jethro Meriwether Hurt, III. Fragile with brittle pages and mold damage.

did.unittitle: Student notebook 1841 January 16 - February 20

scopecontent.p: Volume 3 Notes on materia medica (Dr. Emmet) January 16, 1841 - February 9, 1841 at the University of Pennsylvania): Midwifery -- Labor -- Presentations -- Causes -- Treatment -- Mechanism of presentations -- Hodge (January 20, 1841) -- Wood (February 20, 1841) -- Thraxacum -- Mineral acuscles -- Vegetable astringents -- Kino -- Nervous stimulants (Dr. Wood) -- Cerebral stimulants -- Alcohol -- Opium -- Hemorrhage -- Hyoscyamus -- Camphor -- Belladonna -- Dr. Jackson -- Vascular repair -- Dr. Wood -- Arterial sedatives -- Nux vomica -- Ansenic -- Emetics -- Cathartics.
Gift of Jethro Meriwether Hurt, III. Fragile with brittle pages.

did.unittitle: Student notebook 1919 April 28 - June 7

scopecontent.p: The notebook by Patton K. Pierce, UVA SOM class of 1921, includes Laboratory Exercises in Physiological Chemistry and Pharmacology. Experiments were done on animals including dog, cat, rabbit, turtle, rat, and frog, or various animal organs, with drugs such as alcohol, morphine, ether, caffeine, amyl nitrate, chloroform, opium, and strychnine. Also cocaine was applied to the student's tongue. There is no professor listed but James Alexander Waddell taught Pharmacology, Materia Medica and Toxicology in this time period. According to Southern Medical News, November 1925, "Dr. Patton Kimbrough Pierce, Eutaw [Alabama], aged 30, died August 16 at hospital in Harrisburg, Va. [probably incorrect, probably Alabama] of injuries received when the automobile in which he was driving overturned."
Gift of James D. Webb who found the notebook at a flea market in Virginia. It arrived at the library March 4, 2013.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Lectures on Internal Medicine 1923 September 18 - 1924 May 5

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by Don Carlos Eskew, UVA SOM class of 1924. In the notebook is a slip of paper with Dr Don Carlos Eskew, Buffalo City Hospital, Buffalo, New York written on it. Some of the subjects covered are infectious diseases, heart disease, diseases of the blood, respiratory diseases, arthritis, diseases of the digestive tract, and diabetes mellitus.
Professor: James Carroll Flippin (Professor of Clinical Medicine).
The notebook was acquired from Palinurus Antiquarian Books on May 2, 2015.

did.unittitle: Whiteley's General Chemistry Notes 1885 November 30

scopecontent.p: The title is "Whiteley's General Chemistry Notes" (Complete) Lithographed By Permission And for Sale Only by R. D. Anderson and Bro. University of Virginia. Calvin Whiteley Jr. states that the note of Physics are not full, but the Chemistry notes are full and contain almost everything said during the class. He was helped by the notes of others, especially an old set taken by Mr. Baker Thomas. These notes were then copied by a L.E. Flannagan, M.D. Major sections of the book are Physics, Chemistry Proper, The Atomic Theory, and Organic Chemistry. Five loose pages are about the brain.

The verso of pages have contemporary notes taken by W.P. Miles Jr. who was a student at UVa in the sessions of 1885-86, 1886-87, and 1887-88. Miles signed his name and wrote 18 East Range, University of Virginia, Nov. 30th 1885 in the book. He was from Burnside, Louisianna and studied Chemistry, Natural Philosophy, Modern Languages, and General and Industrial Chemistry. According to "Old Louisiana Plantation Homes And Family Trees" by Herman De Bachelle Seebold at the death of his father, Dr.William Porcher Miles Jr. abandoned the practice of medicine to attend to his large inheritance. He was not a graduate from the University of Virginia School of Medicine.
The book was acquired from John Hellebrand of Palinurus Antiquarian Books in June 2015.

did.unittitle: Student notebook: Therapeutics and Materia Medica1855-1866 [?]

scopecontent.p: The notes were taken by William Joseph Jones of Amherst County, Virginia, and Benjamin Hood. Jones graduated from the University of Virginia in 1865. Other authors may also have contributed; a note later in the book is dated June 18th [18]66.
Schools Attended: Chemistry, Medicine, Physiology and Surgery, and Anatomy.
Professor: John Staige Davis

Fragile condition; loose and detached pages. Originally cataloged in Virgo as a rare book, together with the material in Box 17: Folder 3. From the library of Dr. Peyton N. Rhodes (UVA Class of 1920), grandson of the author, Dr. William Joseph Jones (UVA Medical Class of 1865). The notebook was donated to the Health Sciences Library by Dr. Rhodes's brother-in-law, Dr. Harry L. Archer (UVA Medical Class of 1937). Original cataloging note describes Benjamin Hood as the âfriend and amanuensisâ of William Joseph Jones. Item moved to MS-37 in 2017.
